page_analysis.text_content:
Balconies, decks, & outdoor areas on upper floors

Outdoor areas on upper levels that are roofed DO count toward gross floor area regardless of the design (including whether or not the sides are open).

An outdoor area on an upper floor is considered to be roofed if the eave over that area is deeper than the eave over the rest of the building. This may be illustrated by comparing Roof Plans 1 & 2 of Fig 10.

Fig 10 Balconies

Note: Pop-out balconies are subject to the same evaluation.

Roof Plan 1  Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Does not count because this arbor is substantially open
Area C: Does not count because the overhang is the same size as the overhang around the rest of the house and is considered to be open

Roof Plan 2  Area A: Counts because it is roofed
Area B: Counts because the overhang here is greater than the overhang around the rest of the house, and considered to be roofed
Area C: Does not count because it is open

visual_elements.description: 3D isometric illustration of a building corner showing two roof plans. Roof plan 1 is indicated by a dashed line closer to the building edge, and Roof plan 2 is indicated by a dashed line further out, illustrating different eave depths over a balcony area.

Roof Plan 1 schematic showing a balcony divided into three labeled areas: A (hatched, roofed), B (arbor, open), and C (open overhang). Dimensions indicate 'Width of overhang over the balcony' and 'Width of overhang around the rest of the house'. Area A counts as roofed, B and C do not count.

Roof Plan 2 schematic showing a balcony divided into three labeled areas: A (hatched, roofed), B (hatched, roofed overhang), and C (open). Dimensions indicate 'Width of overhang over the balcony' and 'Width of overhang around the rest of the house'. Areas A and B count as roofed, C does not count.

technical_specifications.value: Deeper than eave over rest of building
